name: Standard Data
headline: Rebuilding the supply of the American manufacturing workforce.
description:
Standard Data builds interactive copilots for highly skilled manufacturing roles.

U.S. manufacturing is in crisis. Despite surging growth, by 2030 the United States will have 4 million unfilled roles.

Automation will not be capable of replacing these skilled roles - to create a safe, prosperous future, we must secure the next generation of manufacturing talent.

founders.name: John Robison, Founder
founders.description: Rebuilding the supply of the American manufacturing workforce.

founders.name: Shaashwat Sharma, Founder
founders.description: Building augmented reality workforce training using AI and AR.

generated_description:
Standard Data is a nascent company founded in 2024, based in San Francisco, and currently a proud member of Y Combinator's Batch S24. With a small team of just two employees, they aim to tackle an urgent issue in the U.S. manufacturing sector: a looming talent crisis. By 2030, it's predicted there will be a staggering 4 million unfilled manufacturing roles in the U.S., a reality that automation simply can't address. The skilled labor these roles demand cannot be replaced by machines; instead, we need to cultivate the next generation of manufacturing talent.

Standard Data initially set out to create interactive copilots specifically designed for high-skill manufacturing roles. Their mission spans beyond just filling positions; it's about revitalizing the American manufacturing workforce by ensuring a robust, skilled talent pool for the future. 

They are actively focused on education, recruiting, and boosting U.S. manufacturing capacity, indicating a strategic approach to foster sustainable growth in this industry. Under the guidance of Group Partner David Lieb, Standard Data is poised to become a pivotal player in reshaping how we think about and build the manufacturing workforce.

For more information, you can explore their [website](https://www.standarddata.com/), which contains insights into their mission, capabilities, and how they plan to recast what they call the "Forge of Freedom." It's not just about jobs; it’s about ensuring a prosperous future for American manufacturing.
